paper_title.en: The recovery of structural relaxation-induced viscoelastic creep strain in bulk and ribbon Pd40Cu30Ni10P20 glass

description.en: The ability of metallic glasses to undergo homogeneous viscous flow is known to decrease strongly as a result of structural relaxation and this effect is commonly considered to be irreversible. The present paper employs creep measurements to show that this ability can be significantly recovered by short-term preannealing in the glass transition region. This technique provides a unique possibility to recover the viscoelastic properties of metallic glasses after these have deteriorated greatly via structural relaxation. (c) 2006 Acta Materialia Inc. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

The recovery of structural relaxation-induced viscoelastic creep strain in bulk and ribbon Pd40Cu30Ni10P20 glass

description.en: The ability of metallic glasses to undergo homogeneous viscous flow is known to decrease strongly as a result of structural relaxation and this effect is commonly considered to be irreversible. The present paper employs creep measurements to show that this ability can be significantly recovered by short-term preannealing in the glass transition region. This technique provides a unique possibility to recover the viscoelastic properties of metallic glasses after these have deteriorated greatly via structural relaxation. (c) 2006 Acta Materialia Inc. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Relationship between the shear viscosity and heating rate of metallic glasses below T-g

description.en: It has been shown that the shear viscosity of bulk and ribbon glassy Pd40Cu30Ni10P20 at temperatures T < T-g (T-g is the glass transition temperature) follows a simple relationship, ln eta(T)=B(T)-ln T, where T is the heating rate and B depends only on temperature. This means, in particular, that ln eta(T) dependencies measured at different heating rates can be superposed by a simple vertical shift and the derivative partial derivative ln eta/partial derivative ln T parallel to(T=const)=-1. Such a behavior is indeed found for glassy Pd40Cu30Ni10P20. The experimental viscosity data derived earlier on other metallic glasses follow the same relationship. It is argued that this relationship originates from stress-oriented irreversible structural relaxation with distributed activation energies.

paper_title.en: Relationship between the shear viscosity and heating rate of metallic glasses below T-g

description.en: It has been shown that the shear viscosity of bulk and ribbon glassy Pd40Cu30Ni10P20 at temperatures T < T-g (T-g is the glass transition temperature) follows a simple relationship, ln eta(T)=B(T)-ln T, where T is the heating rate and B depends only on temperature. This means, in particular, that ln eta(T) dependencies measured at different heating rates can be superposed by a simple vertical shift and the derivative partial derivative ln eta/partial derivative ln T parallel to(T=const)=-1. Such a behavior is indeed found for glassy Pd40Cu30Ni10P20. The experimental viscosity data derived earlier on other metallic glasses follow the same relationship. It is argued that this relationship originates from stress-oriented irreversible structural relaxation with distributed activation energies.

paper_title.en: Stress relaxation of bulk and ribbon glassy Pd40Cu30Ni10P20

description.en: Detailed measurements of linear heating and isothermal stress relaxation of bulk and ribbon glassy Pd40Cu30Ni10P20 below the glass transition temperature have been performed. Using the activation energy spectrum reconstructed from these measurements, the temperature dependence of the shear viscosity has been calculated. It has been found that this dependence agrees with that derived directly from the creep measurements. This provides strong support for understanding the stress relaxation as a result of the stress-oriented irreversible structural relaxation with distributed activation energies. (c) 2005 Acta Materialia Inc. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Stress relaxation of bulk and ribbon glassy Pd40Cu30Ni10P20

description.en: Detailed measurements of linear heating and isothermal stress relaxation of bulk and ribbon glassy Pd40Cu30Ni10P20 below the glass transition temperature have been performed. Using the activation energy spectrum reconstructed from these measurements, the temperature dependence of the shear viscosity has been calculated. It has been found that this dependence agrees with that derived directly from the creep measurements. This provides strong support for understanding the stress relaxation as a result of the stress-oriented irreversible structural relaxation with distributed activation energies. (c) 2005 Acta Materialia Inc. Published by Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
